column4: its a program used to define a process that has a file or socket open and then act accodingly.  There is a reason the posix switches are f, u, c and k

if you do that on a directory it will look to see what processes it is associated with, ie what has it open, since you told it k, it will send kill signals to each of those processes
that included you, your shell so when you do it on a directory your shell has open, you kill your own shell
i thought that if you used the "-m" switch, it only killed processes that have opened files in that directory
-m means mounted, you give it a name and anything that is using that directory and everything under that directory
keep in mind fuser is not a command to be used lightly and misused can cause great damnage
so, if i am in my home, directory and run 'fuser -km /opt/temp'  it should only kill what has opened files in /opt/temp fight
